title: Colic & Digestion: What’s The Link?

content: Though I could barely hear the pediatrician’s voice over my baby’s screaming, I did make out three words that made my heart sink: “It’s probably colic.”
Around 1 month of age, our son’s fussing morphed into full-blown, hours-long screaming sessions that dominated our evenings and left me and my husband utterly drained and discouraged.

The only thing that seemed to slightly help was swaddling his tiny body in a blanket, holding him close, and bouncing on an exercise ball. Those weeks were a blur of fatigue and frustration. And lots and lots of bouncing.

Colic is characterized by bouts of intense, nonstop crying for more than three hours a day and more than three times a week. Babies with colic seem inconsolable. They may arch their backs and clench their fists. And the crying usually kicks in like clockwork, often in the evening hours.

Though the exact cause of colic isn’t yet understood, it’s possible it has something to do with babies’ developing digestive systems. The theory makes sense, since babies with colic appear to be in pain and may even pull up their legs and pass gas.

content: I know from experience that trying something (anything!) to ease the screaming can make you feel less helpless in the face of colic. So if a pediatrician has ruled out other issues and concluded that it’s colic, there are a few things caregivers can try.

One possible cause is food allergies and intolerances. If you’re formula feeding, ask the pediatrician if you should switch to a formulation that may be easier to digest. If you’re breastfeeding, talk to the pediatrician about temporarily nixing possible allergens from your diet, such as milk products.

Another potential trigger is the pain of trapped gas. Take extra time burping your baby after feeding. If you’re bottle feeding, position your baby a bit more upright during feeding so they swallow less air. Pumping a baby’s legs or giving them time on their bellies (while supervised) is worth a shot too.

content: The good news is that colic is temporary, usually easing up around 3 months of age.

content: But in the meantime, colic can do a real number on caregivers. It’s no wonder parents with colicky babies are at increased risk of feelings of depression.

If you have a loved one in your life with a colicky baby, know this: They desperately need a break, and they need help. I still remember the friends who did our laundry, washed our dishes, and brought us meals even when we weakly insisted we were fine and could handle everything.
Better yet, offer to hold and rock the baby for a few hours during the crying spells while parents rest (or leave the house to get some peace and quiet). It’s a lifesaver for worn-out parents.

Eventually, our son’s colic went away. He’s now 16 years old and perfectly healthy. My husband and I now joke that we barely survived colic. Thankfully it’s a distant memory – though we’ll never see an exercise ball without remembering.
